title: When will a lethal confrontation involving the national military forces of North Korea and either South Korea or the United States result in a fatality for either side?
preds: Based on general news and GJP consensus.

It seems certain that this question will time out and reward participants who have chosen the closing date.   However, I think the larger question to ponder here is whether war between the United States and North Korea has now become inevitable.  It's one thing to have North Korea brandishing a few missiles and a few nuclear weapons.  One can cling to the hope that various anti-missile systems will be effective.   However, it seems undeniable that North Korea intends to build thousands of nuclear ICBMs and has the intent to use them.  There is no way that any anti-missile defense will be effective against thousands of incoming warheads.  Like it or not, the United States now faces an existential threat unless North Korea is stopped.   If this war is inevitable, the only question is timing.   If the United States strikes first (and soon), 25 million people may die.  Most casualties will occur in North and South Korea, but some will occur in Japan and the United States.  This will be horrible, but at least one can envision a future beyond it.  Fifty million Koreans will survive and the Korean peninsula can be rebuilt under a unified democratic regime.   Unfortunately, the alternative is far worse.  If war comes later, missile defenses will be overwhelmed.  Hundreds of millions of Americans will die instantly and they will be the lucky ones.   Most American cities will be destroyed.  Infrastructure will be devastated.  The economy will be in ruins.  The power grid will be gone.  Supply chains will be crushed.  Food and fuel will dry up.  No transportation.  No healthcare.  Crime and looting.  Millions of "lucky survivors" will die in the ensuing chaos, and it won't be pretty.  The United States will be finished as country.   Korea will be worse off in this scenario too.  Many more Koreans will be dead, and there will be no "Marshall Plan" to rebuild and stabilize the Korean Peninsula.
Just two weeks left, looking really unlikely.

NBC Politics‏Verified account 
@NBCPolitics JUST IN: North Korea observed moving mobile missile launchers & preparing hard sites in last 48 hours, per 3 U.S. senior military officials

Why has North Korea gone so long without causing fatalities with one of its sneak attacks on South Korea? http://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/24/world/asia/24korea.html  The last significant fatal clash was in Nov. 2010. At that time, North Korea's leader was Kim Jong Il, who died Dec. 17, 2011. Is it possible that with his passing, lethal attacks on South Korea have fallen out of favor? Another  problem with this forecast: the base rate since Kim Jong Un came to "power" (I doubt all that "dictator" talk about him) has been hard for me to calculate because of too few lethal incidents. If my analysis is correct, nowadays North Korea is being ruled by a large committee of seriously geriatric generals, with Kim Jong Un as figurehead, all of  whom are corrupt and want themselves and their heirs to survive the Trump administration.
Slightly lowering forecast further for the moment: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-missiles-idUSKCN1AU04U

Any new Korean war could quickly escalate to catastrophe Brunnstrom (2017) Aug 10, states that: Any new military conflict with North Korea would likely escalate quickly to the use of nuclear weapons, bringing catastrophic casualties not seen since World War Two and an untold economic impact worldwide, former U.S. defense officials and experts say. While the United States has maintained an uneasy calm with North Korea for more than six decades and spikes in tensions are not new, recent supercharged rhetoric between the unpredictable U.S. President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un have heightened the risk of miscalculation that could make that nightmare a reality, they say. On Thursday, North Korea upped the ante by saying it would complete plans by mid-August to fire four intermediate-range missiles over Japan to land near the U.S. Pacific island territory of Guam, after Trump said that any threats by Pyongyang would be "met with fire and fury like the world has never seen." The exchange followed a United Nations resolution tightening sanctions on North Korea after it tested two intercontinental ballistic missiles designed to carry nuclear warheads to the United States. Trump said on Thursday his fire and fury comment was not tough enough. Despite the war of words, for now the U.S. military says there has been no change in its readiness posture in South Korea or elsewhere in Asia. Analysts say they have seen no evidence of any increased alert in North Korea (para. 1-6). Brunnstrom, D. (2017). Any new Korean war could quickly escalate to catastrophe. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-missiles-usa-war-analysis-idUSKBN1AQ2LM Nations start to choose sides in event of North Korea war
As tensions rise, North Korea has found a supporter even as some US allies reaffirmed they would back Washington in the event of an open conflict. Could Germany - and other NATO members - be forced to fight for Trump? Sanders (2017) Aug 11, states that: Amid growing talk of the possibility of open conflict between the United States and North Korea, countries have started to affirm their positions in case violence breaks out on the Korean Peninsula or elsewhere.
Although countries have yet to throw their support behind Pyongyang in the event of a confrontation, North Korea has found supporters in its neighbor China - with some conditions.
"If the US and South Korea carry out strikes and try to overthrow the North Korea regime and change the political pattern of the Korean Peninsula, China will prevent them from doing so," said an editorial in the state-run Global Times.
However, the paper did not recommend Beijing support Pyongyang under all circumstances.
"China should also make clear that if North Korea launches missiles that threaten US soil first and the US retaliates, China will stay neutral," it wrote.
Earlier this week, China's Foreign Ministry urged both North Korea and the United States to "stop provoking each other" and de-escalate the situation in a bid to return to "dialogue and negotiations" (para.1-6). Sanders, L. (2017) Nations start to choose sides in event of North Korea war. Deutsche Welle. Politics. Retrieved from
http://www.dw.com/en/nations-start-to-choose-sides-in-event-of-north-korea-war/a-40049024

It's always a challenge to sift through the news stream today.  Sometimes I try to figure out what opposing parties seem to see as  their BATNA (Best Alternative to a Negotiated Agreement).   It seems to me that the NK BATNA is clear:  keep building more missiles and nuclear weapons no matter what.   At the same time, the US doesn't seem to have a clear idea of its BATNA.   One possible option for the US might be to deploy as many ABM sites as possible, with the idea of shooting down NK missile launches.  Although the record of successful shoot-downs has improved over the years, ABM technical challenges do not assure 100% success.  Also US ABM success seems to have been with short and medium range situations, not ICBM.   In the medium term, the likelihood of success for this defense strategy will deteriorate.  It will be overwhelmed by the building of hundreds of missiles and the eventual application of MIRV capability.   I think the true BATNA for the US is to accept the inevitability of a second Korean War, and to make preparations to win it decisively and quickly in the near term, while that can still be done.  I don't think that this understanding will be reached in the next month or two,  I'm also betting that NK will not act immediately.  Apparently they still have a little work to do to perfect their reentry heat shields.

On checking my history of forecasting this question I can see that as NK does something provocative I have assumed the risk of a lethal confrontation has increased and then as nothing happened it reduced again. 
This round is different its the US and UN that have increased sanctions on NK (so NK has been provoked), 
There is some suspicion of possible fake news about the suggestion that NK might have miniaturized a nuclear bomb so that it would fit in the ICBM it has been developing.   This same story or something very similar has been reported earlier this year, last year and regularly since 2013. So it is not really news today. Maybe it is politically convenient to make a lot of noise about it now? It is not believed that NK has the capability to start a nuclear war with the continental USA.  (No evidence a NK ICBM can get through re-entry). 
The thing Kim wants is to have the capability to hit the continental USA with a nuclear bomb. Next best is for the USA to believe he has that capability. He does not seem any risk of being overthrown (as far as I can tell). Provoking an incident that is not part of tests to get his nuclear ICBMs working would not seem to be useful to him. 
On the other hand Trump might be tempted to show NK how much "fire and fury" the US has, but the US military probably has sense to take more care.

I suspect cooler (and wiser) heads will prevail in the current climate. As one commenter pointed out, Kim Jung-un is not the lunatic that Western media portrays. It would be disastrous for everyone if a shooting war started - especially with nuclear weapons in the mix. The question is worded in such a way that one may think a brief exchange of gunfire between South and North Korea will result in a few deaths. The more likely scenario is some incident quickly leads to an escalation and the gloves come off. In the ensuing conflict, many will die. 
Until things cool down, it is not unreasonable to expect the emergence of a serious conflict. We have to remember that the U.S. administration is woefully inexperienced in this type of situation. And, quite frankly, the administration is over its head in most issues related to geopolitics.

8/9/17: Now seeing pushback from at least some U.S. political leaders to Trump's inflamed N.K. rhetoric.. It's noted (below) that a "preemptive" U.S. strike would (normally) require Congressional approval.. http://www.cnn.com/2017/08/08/politics/lawmakers-trump-fire-fury-north-korea-mccain/index.html http://www.cbsnews.com/news/north-korea-threatens-attack-guam/ http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/donald-trump-north-korea-1999-meet-the-press_us_598a86aee4b0a66b8bafa026

rhetoric is heating up between US and NK,  http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-40871416 North Korea says it is considering missile strikes near the US territory of Guam, just hours after President Donald Trump threatened Pyongyang with "fire and fury". The North's official news agency said it was mulling a plan to fire medium-to-long-range rockets around Guam, where US strategic bombers are based. The statement marks a sharp rise in rhetoric between the two countries. The UN recently approved further economic sanctions against the country. President Trump's comments followed a media report that claimed the North had made a nuclear warhead small enough to fit inside its missiles. The Washington Post report, which cited US intelligence officials, suggests North Korea is developing nuclear weapons capable of hitting the US at a much faster rate than expected. The North's official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) said its military was "carefully examining the operational plan for making an enveloping fire at the areas around Guam with medium-to-long-range strategic ballistic rocket Hwasong-12". It said the plan would be reported to the Supreme Command after "full examination and completion" and put into practice at the order of leader Kim Jong-un, South Korea's Yonhap news agency reported. The heated rhetoric between the US and North Korea intensified after Pyongyang tested two intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBM) in July, claiming it now had the ability to hit the US. Mr Trump told reporters on Tuesday: "North Korea best not make any more threats to the US. They will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen." Veteran US Senator John McCain was sceptical about Mr Trump's statement. "The great leaders that I have seen they don't threaten unless they are ready to act and I'm not sure that President Trump is ready to act." said Senator McCain.

8/8/17: Trump comments (ref. below) could be (ratcheted-up) "sabre-rattling", but I'm not in a position to be 100% certain at this point...

reaffirm as frozen conflict. One observer ( and despite claims to prophecy) cannot be assumed to be reliable is George Friedman. Here is his view that came across my desk and I do  not endorse it at all, I hope he is wrong. I wish I could refute it: but who really knows? here it is: from https://geopoliticalfutures.com/north-korea-stares-abyss/ "Kim has only bad choices, but for a few reasons, the least bad choice for him is war. First, it’s possible that the U.S. is bluffing and that nothing will come from this episode. Second, it’s possible that China or Russia will intervene to save him, though neither country is up to the task of fighting a conventional war with the U.S. (Neither country is all that interested in saving the Kim government either.) It’s possible that South Korea, afraid for Seoul, will block the attack. It’s possible that Japan will get involved. It’s possible that the U.S. attack will fail. It’s possible that the nuclear program is further along than everyone thinks and that that will deter an attack.
Barring this last scenario, it seems to me that the U.S. cannot refuse to go to war unless North Korea capitulates. North Korea cannot capitulate. Neither country wants to go to war, but neither can accept what is happening without war. My best guess is that North Korea currently does not have a weapon that could be readily delivered by stealth, and it would have to be demonstrated before an attack began, not after. I think we are looking at the prospect of a few weeks of quiet diplomacy and noisy public threats that will lead to war.
The signs are all there. The United States does not deploy the force it has deployed unless it’s serious. Such was the case in Desert Storm, in Kosovo, and in the 2003 invasion of Iraq. By sending the USS Nimitz, the U.S. is telling North Korea, in no uncertain terms, that war is approaching. Now, it is North Korea’s move. Pyongyang had been quiet for a few days until firing a missile on May 28, which landed in the Sea of Japan. Still, you have to consider that North Korea is staring down into the abyss". My estimation is that this analysis rests on a series of faulty syllogisms. Each actor has much more to lose than gain and like
the US- Russia standoff in 10-62
with rational actors and good communications

U.S., China talk firmer U.N. response to North Korea's missiles: diplomats Nichols (2017) Tue May 2, states that: The United States is negotiating with China on a possible stronger U.N. Security Council response - such as sanctions - to North Korea's repeated ballistic missile launches, which the 15-member body normally condemns in a statement, diplomats said. It was not immediately clear how open Beijing might be to new sanctions. The council has traditionally boosted sanctions in response to North Korea's five nuclear tests and two long-range rocket launches. Sanctions were first imposed on Pyongyang in 2006. North Korea has in the past year stepped up its missile tests, firing dozens of various types of rockets, according to South Korea. The most recent test, which failed, came on Friday following a U.N. Security Council meeting on North Korea, chaired by U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson. "The cumulative actions of the DPRK (North Korea) since their last nuclear test compel us to look at a range of measures that would apply pressure," said a spokesman for the U.S. Permanent Mission to the United Nations on Tuesday. "As Secretary Tillerson said on Friday, business as usual is not an option. We are exploring options for a response to this series of provocations with our Security Council colleagues," the spokesman said. Tillerson on Friday urged the Security Council to act before North Korea does. The Trump administration has been aggressively pressing Beijing to rein in its ally and neighbor North Korea, warning that all options were on the table if Pyongyang persists with its nuclear and missile development. But China has said military threats would not help the situation and has accused the United States of fueling tensions on the Korean Peninsula. Beijing on Tuesday reiterated its opposition to the deployment of the U.S.' THAAD anti-missile defense system in South Korea and urged it to be halted immediately. The last round of complex sanctions imposed by the Security Council took three months to negotiate following Pyongyang's fifth nuclear test in September. Those measures aimed to cut North Korea's annual export revenue by a quarter. Traditionally, the United States and China have negotiated new sanctions before involving remaining council members. U.N. diplomats said the current talks were still just between the pair (para. 1-11). Nichols, M. (2017). U.S., China talk firmer U.N. response to North Korea's missiles: diplomats. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-nuclear-un-idUSKBN17Y2AG

Japanese ships join U.S. carrier for drills as it nears Korean waters Kubo and Kelly (2017) Sun Apr 23, states that: Two Japanese destroyers on Sunday began an exercise with the U.S. Carl Vinson carrier strike group in the Western Pacific as it approaches waters around the Korean peninsula, Japan's navy said. The two Japanese warships, the Samidare and Ashigara, left western Japan on Friday to join the Carl Vinson in a show of solidarity as the United States confronts North Korea over its ballistic missile program and nuclear tests. The destroyers will "practice a variety of tactics" with the U.S. strike group, the Japan Maritime Self Defence Force (MSDF) said in a statement (para. 1-3). Kubo, N. & Kelly, T. (2017). Japanese ships join U.S. carrier for drills as it nears Korean waters. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from

Those news stories about U.S. aircraft carrier Vinson (and associated fleet) having rushed away from Singapore and heading for North Korea -- NOT SO! From SitRep: Foreign Policy <fp@foreignpolicy.com>	Tue, Apr 18, 2017 5:04 am
Where in the world…For at least a week, we’ve all been speculating where the USS Carl Vinson carrier strike group might be, after leaving a port visit in Singapore and cancelling another visit to Australia in the midst of increasing tensions with North Korea. But Defense News’ Chris Cavas has figured it out, discovering that the ships aren’t parked off the Korean coast, but rather are operating several hundred miles south of Singapore, taking part in scheduled exercises with Australian forces in the Indian Ocean.  “On Saturday – according to photographs released by the U.S. Navy – the carrier passed north through the Sunda Strait, the passage between the Indonesian islands of Sumatra and Java. It's about 3,500 miles from Korea,” Cavas writes. And there you have it.

Initial assessment based on US-DPRK rhetoric and DPRK weapons testing. I would anticipate a DPRK nuclear test before October. The US has not been able to stop these tests with cyberwarfare (if that has indeed been the case with the missile tests - still unconfirmed). DPRK has in the past randomly shelled the ROK. Nothing convincing yet suggests the ROK or US is committed to abandoning caution and will provoke the DPRK. The Trump administration has so far walked back many Presidential tweets/campaign pledges on foreign policy. 
The discrepancy between the prob for Apr-Jun and Jul-Sep periods is purely due to the date today. We also got through the Easter weekend DPRK parade without incident. The high numbers reflect the apparent red line drawn by the administration, especially the statement that the US has 'lost strategic patience' with the DPRK. All evidence suggests that the current admin will value the use of the military and intends to contrast itself with any perceived weakness of the Obama administration.

Kim Jong-un does international relations differently to everyone else. He knows that the US does not dare to use nuclear weapons against him, nor does China. He knows that China, the US and SK are aware that NK could attack SK with conventional weapons which could kill thousands of people. Although China could beat NK in a war, China is afraid that NK might go down fighting and take SK with it, leaving China to pick up the pieces. If SK were attacked it could no doubt hit back, but at a high cost. 
All this means that retaliation by China, USA or SK to provocation by NK has to be very carefully balanced; too little and they appear weak; too much and they risk an escalation by NK. As Kim does not care if a few of his subjects are killed he is quite capable to taking some action that results in a small number of South Koreans being killed (e.g. sinking a fishing boat or two, shelling boarder guards) and daring SK (or the US) to hit back. If they do not hit back Kim would count that as a glorious victory, if they do hit back as a tit for tat action Kim can use it as propaganda in NK to prove that NK is surrounded by countries that are planning to attack NK. Experience has shown that SK and the US have no real answer to this sort of action by NK.   
The number of border incidence has reduced as the provocations of atomic bomb tests and missile tests has increased, but that does not mean that NK could not go back to shelling, torpedoing ships, planting land mines and just shooting people if it feels it need to make point. With the US sending ships towards NK and the THAAD system on its way, NK may decide to do something.

The US action in Syria might show NK that the US might retaliate to provocations in other parts of the world. It might convince China to try harder to stop NK. 
There is of course the risk that if the action in Syria appears to have got results it might encourage Trump to think that he could do something of a similar nature to NK, but I would expect that others in the US Government would stop him.
Moved one point from Jan-March to April-June, basic rollover due to time, but also think April-June has a greater chance of being eventful in this regard.

U.S. says 'all options on table' to deal with North Korea Nichols (2017) Wed Mar 8, states that: The United States on Wednesday said "all options are on the table" to deal with North Korea and dismissed China's suggestion of a "dual suspension" of U.S. and South Korea military drills and Pyongyang's missile and nuclear tests. "We are not dealing with a rational person," U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley said of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un after the United Nations Security Council discussed North Korea's launch of four ballistic missiles on Monday. "It is an unbelievable, irresponsible arrogance that we are seeing coming out of Kim Jong Un at this time," Haley said. She said the administration of U.S. President Donald Trump was reevaluating how it would handle North Korea and that "all options were on the table," adding: "We are making those decisions now and we will act accordingly." North Korea fired the missiles into the sea off Japan's coast in response to the annual U.S.-South Korea military drills, which Pyongyang sees as preparation for war. Pyongyang has fired dozens of missiles and conducted two of its five nuclear tests in the past year in defiance of U.N. resolutions In a statement sent to U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres on Wednesday, North Korea's Foreign Ministry warned that it would "reduce the bases of aggression and provocation to ashes with its invincible Hwasong rockets tipped with nuclear warheads and reliably defend the security of the country and its people's happiness in case the U.S. and the South Korean puppet forces fire even a single bullet at the territory of the DPRK." 
Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi said on Wednesday that the tests by the North and the joint drills across the border in South Korea were causing tension to increase like two "accelerating trains coming toward each other," suggesting a "dual suspension" to allow all sides to return to negotiations (para. 1-7). Nichols, M. (2017) U.S. says 'all options on table' to deal with North Korea. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-missiles-un-idUSKBN16F24S

Nuclear tests and ballistics testing: a clear pattern to DPRK provocations. Asymetric response to annual US ROK exercises 
Not conventional attacks- 
See latest test.
http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/northkorea/2017/03/06/0401000000AEN20170306001151315.html
SEOUL, March 6 (Yonhap) -- North Korea on Monday fired what could be an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) into the East Sea in an apparent protest against the ongoing joint military drills between South Korea and the United States, Seoul's Joint Chiefs of Staff said. The projectile was launched from an area near the North's Dongchang-ri long-range missile site at 7:36 a.m. and flew across the country before splashing into the East Sea, JCS said in a text message. "We are conducting an analysis on the projectile to determine its type and flight range. It will take a while before we come up with a final analysis (based on U.S. satellite data)," the JCS said. It could be an ICBM capable of reaching the U.S. mainland, an official at the defense ministry said. On Friday, Pyongyang threatened to conduct more missile firings in response to the two-month-long Foal Eagle exercise between Seoul and Washington, which lasts through April. The Rodong Sinmun, the ruling party's official newspaper, said in a commentary that "new types of strategic weapons will soar" if Seoul and Washington continue their annual war drills, which the North claims to be a preparation for a war against it.

This is a relatively easy prediction to make.  Trump's current foreign policy focuses primarily on the Middle East, China and Russia.  North Korea and South Korea have not been discussed at length either on the campaign trail, or his actual presidency.  As such, I find it highly improbable Trump would take interest in North-Western Asian affairs.  This translates into extremely low probabilities for an armed conflict to occur between South Korea, North Korea and USA.

Missile Shield Against North Korea Shakes Delicate Asia Ties Cheng and Jun (2017) Feb. 20, state that: SEOUL—A proposed U.S.-built missile defense system to help South Korea guard against growing threats from its North Korean nemesis is roiling relations between Seoul and Beijing.
Many South Koreans believe China is retaliating against their government, targeting pop stars, companies and individuals over the defense array, which Beijing has denounced as a threat to its own security. The KoreanInstitute for National Unification, a state-backed think tank, has tallied up dozens of reported cases of suspected retaliation.
China hasn’t confirmed any reprisals but has at times belied a link between its actions and South Korea’s planned deployment of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense, or Thaad. The two nations’ foreign ministers traded barbs over Thaad this past weekend at a security conference in Munich.
Meanwhile, China’s official Xinhua news agency, in an English-language commentary, warned the South Korean conglomerate Lotte Group on Sunday that it was “playing with fire” over its plan to allow Seoul to deploy Thaad on its land.
The dispute adds a new wrinkle to Northeast Asia’s complex network of alliances and antipathies as Pyongyang moves closer to its goal of developing a nuclear-tipped missile that can reach the continental U.S. Last week, it launched another missile test that experts say advanced that goal. The killing last week of North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un’s half brother in a Malaysian airport added to Mr. Kim’s reputation for ruthlessness and unpredictability, sparking new fears in South Korea. Officials in Seoul hold Mr. Kim responsible.
Seoul recently launched a task force to hear complaints from South Korean businesses operating in China and discuss possible countermeasures to Beijing’s alleged retaliation over Thaad. Some lawmakers have called for a formal complaint at the World Trade Organization.
“We will keep raising the issue with the China side resolutely and continuously, while judging facts objectively and responding reasonably,” said Korean Vice Trade Minister Woo Tae-hee recently (para.1-7). Cheng, J. & Jun, K. (2017) Missile Shield Against North Korea Shakes Delicate Asia Ties. The Wall Street Journal. World. China. Retrieved from
https://www.wsj.com/articles/missile-shield-against-north-korea-shakes-delicate-asia-ties-1487592013

The Trump administration is primarily focused on domestic policy.  They are not likely to provoke a confrontation with North Korea.  The only way in which this issue could occur is if the United States or South Korea is forced to respond to actions of North Korea.  Because the United States is now so unpredictable it is unlikely the North Korea will make aggressive moves.  They like to "rattle their sword", but Kim Jong Il values his position, comfort and privilege above all things.  If he starts a war he will lose everything he has, and is therefore unlikely to put his personal comfort at risk.

Trump is pissing off the entire world -- friend and foe alike. Regimes like North Korea have been biding their time just waiting for an auspicious time period in which to act. Now, when Trump insults and demeans countries and world leaders, North Korea will jump at the chance to show how "masculine" their leader is, compared to ours with the tiny hands!

Post Korean War, North and South Korea have been involved in a number of (minor) skirmishes, with N. Korea often acting as the provocateur. They (N. Korea) have fired multiple artillery barrages into S. Korea, with a swift counter-battery response from S. Korea soon after. There was also the sinking of the ROKS Cheonan, which was blamed on a N. Korean torpedo, although there isn't enough evidence to support that claim. Outside of these events, I am not aware of any other major confrontations. Currently, there do not seem to be any major arms build-up or mobilizations occurring that could indicate a potential conflict. That being said, the overall situation in the South/East China Sea region is quite rickety, and a misstep by any of the neighbouring nations (Japan, China etc.) could set off a conflict within S. Korea as well.  I do not believe such an event will occur in 2017; neither army is likely to be prepared to wage a war, and the threats of casualties and massive political destabilization are likely to prevent an escalation from happening right now.

The Correlates of War project lists 351 Militarized Interstate Dispute Incident Participants which were either North or South Korea between 1993 and 2010. Of these, 11 resulted in fatalities. So, we should expect around 5 incidents in any three month period, of which only 3% result in fatalities, meaning a roughly 14% probability of any fatalities in the same three-month period. This does not account for the fact the these probabilities should be correlated, and the incident history further mined for patterns (seasonality, annual events, etc.). Never-the-less, it's an adequate back-of-the-envelope estimate.

NK provocations in recent years have been in the form of missile test and nuclear tests rather than shellings and sinking ships. I would not think NK, SK or the USA would have anything to gain by a direct confrontation that could turn lethal. The only circumstance that I can envisage is if NK wanted to test if the USA (under Trump) was still willing to protect SK from NK aggression. (Trump has implied that protecting other countries may not be one of his priorities.) But to really test America's resolve would require more than a minor incident and NK much realise that an unpredictable USA could react in unpredictable ways, that as a Japanese leader once said may not be necessarily be to the NK advantage.

North Korea is riding on thin ice. Of utmost importance is maintaining, for its people, a semblance of national strength in the face of challenges from the outside, and therefore any provocation--a fly-over or a sail-by--by other nations must have a response, and the nation must continue with its own shows of military power. I think that the military build-up is largely symbolic. However, NK has to be careful not to go too far. The UN, U.S. and other partners have just recently slapped them with the toughest sanctions applied to any country in decades for their brazenness. Aside from sanctions, NK also relies heavily on aid from other countries, including South Korea. So they will not want to do anything that will provoke these countries to retract that aid. The DPRK's power seems to be somewhat fragile, and it relies on a balance of economic prosperity and military might, among other things. It doesn't want to rock the boat too much. Moreover, the DPRK is not interested in outright warfare. They know that they U.S. and others would intervene.

Browne and Rizzo (2016) states that: Washington (CNN)Director of National Intelligence James Clapper said Tuesday it's a "lost cause" to try to get North Korea to surrender its nuclear weapons -- a view that runs counter to official US policy. 
"They are not going to do that," Clapper said in remarks at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York, where he touched on a number of foreign policy challenges facing the US -- including a scenario under which the Russians might try to down American fighter plans in Syria.
"They are under siege and they are very paranoid. So the notion of giving up their nuclear capability, whatever it is, is a nonstarter with them," Clapper added. "The best we could probably hope for is some sort of a cap." 
The North Korean regime views its nuclear program as "their ticket to survival," the intel director said (para. 1-4). Browne, R. & Rizzo, J. (2016). US intel chief: North Korea will never give up nukes. CNN. Retrieved from
http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/25/politics/clapper-north-korea-nuclear-weapons-lost-cause/index.html

North Korea lashes out at threat of more sanctions AP (2016) states that: PYONGYANG, North Korea (AP) — North Korean officials lashed out Monday at efforts in the United Nations to strengthen sanctions following the North's latest missile launches and nuclear test in September.
The officials told an Associated Press Television crew in Pyongyang that sanctions targeting the nuclear and missile tests are "criminal documents" and accused the United States of orchestrating the condemnation.
The United Nations has imposed sanctions on North Korea since 2006 for its nuclear tests and rocket launches. Last week, the U.N. Security Council called on members to "redouble their sanction efforts." (para. 1-3). AP. (2016) .North Korea lashes out at threat of more sanctions. Yahoo News. Retrieved from

Concur with Isgold7's excellent summary.   Missiles and nukes are Kim Jung-Un's communication tools and his goal is to prevent US-ROK actions until he has them ready.

The North Korean leadership has two things driving here:  1) How it perceives the rest of the world sees it's standing in the world order, and 2) How it sees relations with the US unfolding with the new US administration after 1 January 2017.  The demonstrated path on Item #1 continues to indicate that North Korea will continue to exert itself as a participant in the world nuclear order; therefore, continued shows of strength.  Next, the change in US administrations introduces a political unknown/variable to the North Koreans, and they have always reacted with a show of strength (at least in their eyes) when it comes to sending a message.  This indicates to me that a provocative act will occur where North Korea can: 1) Continue to posture its world role, and 2) Let the US know that it is not afraid of the new administration, irrespective of the elected candidate.

and since ascension to the throne, Kim III has expedited testing of nuclear testing, weaponization and ballistic missiles. ( See Musudan and September 2016  nuclear test No. 5) There have been no reported casualties since KIm III commenced his reign,
Why?
Kim III will not risk triggering any military confrontation until The DPRK nuclear deterrent is ready and, (perhaps more importantly) perceived as capable of   launching an IRBM that can  accurately target, ROK, Japan and Guam. That is the main purpose of the nuclear deterrent, to prevent US and or ROK from initiating regime change via an amphibious landing or other means. I assume KIm III is an absolute dictator with complete command, control, and communications with the DPRK armed forces. Last result, KIm III desires is any lethal comfrontation until he can hold ROK and Japan as nuclear hostages. As the estimated time for Kim III  to complete his deterrent is (coincidentally) about October 2017;
there will be no DPRK initiated lethal comfrontations, and I see no possible US-ROK initiated lethal confrontations during that time period. Short of an accident, there is no chance of such a confrontation.
Morover, while Kim III record has been one of continued provocations, Kim III has no record of such a confrontation and actually has an imperative of preventing any incident that could  provide even a plausible rationale for a US/ROK pre-emptive strike. Initiation of conflict resulting in fatality will result in serious conflagration and escalation of war on the peninsula. As far as I can tell, there have been no fatalities since 2013, and prior to that 2010, and prior to that 2002 (according to wikipedia - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_border_incidents_involving_North_Korea#2010s). So since 2000 (16 years) there have been 3 fatal incidents - c. one every 5 years.  Therefore base likelihood of having incident in next year is 1 in 5 = 20%. However, tensions appear high currently due to heightened number of nuclear tests and threats (apparently Ban Ki Moon has said he has never seen such heightened tension on the Korean Peninsula).  So add an additional 3% likelihood. Weight the 23% likelihood broadly evenly between the other periods
There have been about 12 transborder military incidents involving NK since 2010. Two of these were lethal, both in 2010.

I think fatalities are likely to occur without there being any media coverage of the incidents. I think these incidents may well have already taken place on several occasions, yet it has been possible to conceal this in order to maintain a certain status quo.
This has been relatively rare in past, and not much sign lately of anybody acting more strangely than usual.
